questions.text: Which of the following does not play a role in fetal growth?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth hormone

 

Growth hormone (GH) does not play a significant role in fetal growth. The primary regulators of fetal growth are insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) and thyroxine. IGFs are critical for cellular growth and differentiation during fetal development. Thyroxine, a thyroid hormone, is essential for brain development and overall growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin-like growth factors: These play a crucial role in fetal growth by promoting cellular growth and differentiation.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: This hormone is vital for proper development, particularly for brain development and metabolic regulation.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because growth hormone does not significantly influence fetal growth, while IGFs and thyroxine do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, while insulin-like growth factors and thyroxine are crucial for proper fetal development.

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polio

 

While infants can acquire polio antibodies from their mothers, this immunity is not consistent and can fade during infancy. Therefore, newborns are given a 0 dose of polio drops to ensure protection against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Maternal antibodies against tetanus can provide significant immunity to the newborn. Pregnant women are advised to receive the Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy, ideally between 27-36 weeks of gestation. Maternal antibodies produced from the vaccine can protect the newborn against tetanus.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Maternal antibodies provide some protection, but it's less reliable than tetanus


Protection duration is shorter (1-2 months)

 

Option D. Measles: Maternal antibodies help protect the baby from measles until about 9 months of age. After that, the efficacy of maternal antibodies decreases, which is why the measles vaccine is given at 9 months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B + C (Posterolateral variety and Bochdalek hernia)

 

The most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the Bochdalek hernia, which occurs in the posterolateral part of the diaphragm. This type of hernia typically presents with abdominal organs, such as the intestines, herniating into the chest cavity, leading to respiratory distress in newborns due to lung compression. Bochdalek hernias account for about 85-90% of all congenital diaphragmatic hernias, making them the most common type.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Anteromedial variety: This is a less common form of congenital diaphragmatic hernia and typically occurs in the anterior or medial portion of the diaphragm, which is not the usual presentation associated with congenital cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the Bochdalek hernia, which is located in the posterolateral part of the diaphragm.

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

The chloride level of sweat is evaluated in cystic fibrosis.

 

CYSTIC FIBROSIS

 

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Mutation in chromosome no. 7
  • Primary defect: CFTR gene [Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene on chromosome 7q31.2]
  • Other defects: Chloride channels, Potassium channels, Epithelial sodium channels

 

 

  • Sweat ducts normally absorb sodium from lumen which decreases in CF causing salty sweat.
  • Excessive loss of salt in the sweat is there. Other ducts are obstructed.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

Hallmark of cystic fibrosis –

 

High sodium and chloride levels Sweat chloride level is >60mEq/L in 2 occasions Airways, pancreas & GIT - Normally sodium uptake is there from luminal fluid but in CF there is increase of sodium and water uptake from lumen causing thick, viscid secretions.

 

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Phenylketonuria occurs due to absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme, leading to phenylketonuria. Diagnosis is made by Ferric chloride test, Guthrie test.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of the tissue enzyme glucocerebrosidase that splits glucose from glucosylceramide, resulting in accumulation of the latter in cells of the reticuloendothelial system. Diagnosis is made by measuring glucocerebrosidase levels in leukocytes or skin fibroblasts. Serum chitotriosidase levels are elevated.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta causes defective type-1 collagen. Presents with a triad of blue sclera, Fragile bones, Early deafness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) West syndrome

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

 

  • West syndrome is a severe generalised epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:
    • Infantile spasm
    • Developmental regression
    • Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes.

 

Treatment of West syndrome includes:

 

  • ACTH
  • Vigabatrin when associated with tuberous sclerosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: Young adults who have juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) commonly experience myoclonic jerks in the morning. Valproate is helpful in treating benign myoclonic epilepsy, whereas levetiracetam is helpful in treating severe myoclonic epilepsies.

 

Option B. Rolandic epilepsy: Rolandic epilepsy is benign epilepsy seen in children. They present at night or while awakening.

 

Option D. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS): Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a rare but severe form of childhood epilepsy characterized by a triad of multiple seizure types, characteristic EEG findings, and intellectual impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

questions.text: A pediatric surgeon is planning the optimal timing for cleft palate surgery on a young patient. For the repair of the soft palate, at what age should the surgery ideally be performed? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 months

 

Soft palate repair is typically performed between 3 to 6 months of age. This early intervention is crucial as it facilitates better outcomes in terms of speech development and minimizes the risks associated with feeding difficulties. Early repair allows for more normal development of speech patterns as the child grows, which is vital for effective communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The timing of cleft palate surgery –

 

  • For the soft palate, surgery is ideally conducted at 3 -6 months
  • For the hard palate repair is done at 12-15 months.

questions.text: Gene involved in Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GABRA-1

 

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), also known as Janz syndrome, is a common type of generalized epilepsy that typically manifests in adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and absence seizures. A mutation in the GABRA-1 gene, which encodes for the alpha-1 subunit of the GABA(A) receptor, has been linked to juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The GABA(A) receptor is crucial in mediating inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain, and mutations in this gene can disrupt normal neuronal function, leading to the seizures characteristic of JME.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CHYNN-1: This gene is not associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The correct genes associated with JME include GABRA-1 and others like CLNC2, EFHC1, and CACNB4.

 

Option C. FMR-1: The FMR-1 gene is associated with Fragile X syndrome, which is a leading cause of inherited intellectual disability, not juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because not all the genes listed are involved in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. Only GABRA-1 from the options given is directly linked to JME.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The GABRA-1 gene is a key genetic factor in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.text: Which can be used as an alternative to breast milk in low birth weight (LBW) child? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Human donor milk

 

  • Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants
  • Low birth weight refers to birth weight less than 2500 grams due to preterm birth or intrauterine growth restriction or both
  • All low birth weight babies should be fed only by breast milk, regardless of the feeding method
  • Expressed breast milk or human donor milk should be given to infants fed by paladai or gastric tube

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cow milk: Cow milk is not given because it is rich in casein. Casein causes constipation, colicky pain and cow milk protein allergy.

 

Option B. Preterm formula & Option C. Term formula: Formula feeds, including term formula feed for infants weighing ≥1500 g at birth and preterm formula feed for very low birth weight infants, can be given when there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick or human donor milk is not available or toned milk is not available.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

 

The clinical presentation and EEG findings are consistent with infantile spasms, which is seen in WEST Syndrome. The drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in WEST syndrome is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Drug of choice of baby with infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is vigabtrin.

 

Infantile spasms typically present as clusters of sudden, brief, symmetric, and often flexor or extensor jerks of the limbs or trunk. The spasms are usually associated with regression of developmental milestones, including loss of acquired skills such as smiling, babbling, or sitting up. Hypsarrhythmia, which is a chaotic and disorganized pattern of high-amplitude, asynchronous spikes and slow waves on EEG, is a characteristic finding in infantile spasms.

 

ACTH is the most effective medication for the treatment of infantile spasms. It is believed to work by decreasing the inflammation and abnormal electrical activity in the brain that is thought to be responsible for the spasms. ACTH is typically administered as a daily injection, usually for a duration of several weeks. The response to treatment is usually monitored with serial EEGs, which should show improvement in the hypsarrhythmia pattern.

 

West syndrome is severe generalized epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:

 

  1. Infantile epileptic spasms
  2. Developmental regression
  3. Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is the second line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not typically used for treating infantile spasms associated with West Syndrome.

 

Option C. Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic medication but is not the first-line treatment for West Syndrome.

 

Option D. Phenobarbitone: Phenobarbitone is the first line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not the preferred treatment for infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

 

The most appropriate next step for a child with a VP shunt who presents with symptoms suspicious for meningitis is to obtain blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples from the shunt tap and/or lumbar puncture. It is important to diagnose and treat meningitis quickly in patients with VP shunts, as untreated meningitis can cause shunt malfunction and other complications.

 

The diagnosis of meningitis in a child with a VP shunt requires obtaining blood cultures and CSF samples. Blood cultures are needed to identify the causative organism, while CSF samples are used to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the infection. CSF can be obtained either through a shunt tap or a lumbar puncture, depending on the child's clinical status and the availability of the appropriate resources.

 

VP shunt fluid is usually obtained from a reservoir that is easily accessible subcutaneously. After sterile preparation, the reservoir should be punctured with a 25-gauge needle. The risk of introducing infection is also low (4.1%).

 

 

Ventriculoperitoneal shunt:

 

 

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CS) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

 

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following:

 

  • Infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, usually from Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Shunt over drainage (slit ventricles)
  • Shunt nephritis
  • Shunt disconnection
  • Shunt obstruction
  • Inguinal hernia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch: as the patient is showing features of complication, wait and watch will not be the appropriate answer.

 

Option B. Check shunt patency by nuclear study: we should check the patency of the shunt but as the patient is showing signs of meningitis we should do a CSF analysis by shunt tap.

 

Option C. Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture: the main source of infection is from the shunt, so taking CSF sample from there is best.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cri-du-chat syndrome

 

  • Cri-du-chat syndrome: partial deletion of short arm of Chr 5, leads to cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.
  • Bloom syndrome: rare autosomal recessive disorder, characterized by short stature, sun sensitivity, predeposition of development of cancer and genomic instability.
  • Angelman syndrome: caused by deletion in maternal chromosome 15 or paternal uniparental disomy, affects nervous system, delayed development, intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, and ataxia.
  • Fragile X syndrome: genetic disorder, also known as Martin-Bell syndrome, most common cause of inherited mental retardation (among X-linked disorders), intellectual disability, and autism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bloom syndrome: features are:

 

  • Short stature
  • Sun sensitive rash over the nose and nose and cheeks
  • Immune deficiency 
  • Insulin resistance that resembles Type 2 Diabetes

 

The question doesn’t mention such feature. Therefore, bloom syndrome is not the right answer

 

Option C. Angelman syndrome: remember “angel is the mother” therefore, in this syndrome maternal gene is deleted. It is one of the examples of uniparental disomy. The clinical features are:

 

 

  1. Maternal gene is deleted
  2. Paternal gene is doubled
  3. Dev delay
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Microcephaly
  6. Hyperactive
  7. Spontaneous laughter - Happy Puppets
  8. Hypertonia
  9. UBE3A GENE ON Chr 15 is defective/absent

 

Option D. fragile x syndrome: it is the second most common non preventable cause of mental retardation. The features are:

 

  1. Male patient
  2. Large ears
  3. Large testes
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Nose will NOT be large

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cri-du-chat syndrome is identified by a partial deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, leading to distinctive clinical features such as a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.

choices.text: Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Day- night variation of FEV1 > 12%

 

A day-night variation of FEV1 > 12%, is not a standard measure used in the diagnosis of asthma. While diurnal variation in peak expiratory flow (PEF) is often used to monitor asthma control, it is not specifically measured by FEV1, and a >12% variation in FEV1 between day and night is not typically used as a diagnostic criterion for asthma.

 

Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs) are essential in diagnosing and managing asthma, particularly in identifying airflow obstruction and its reversibility. Specific findings on PFTs suggestive of asthma include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation: An increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) by more than 15% after the administration of a bronchodilator like salbutamol is indicative of reversible airway obstruction, which is characteristic of asthma.

 

Option B. FEV1/FVC< 80%: A FEV1/FVC (Forced Vital Capacity) ratio of less than 80% is suggestive of obstructive lung disease, including asthma. This ratio decreases because of the increased airway resistance in asthmatic patients.

 

Option D. Decrease in FEV1>12% after exercise: A decrease in FEV1 by more than 15% after exercise is a sign of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, a common feature of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in FEV1 > 12% after bronchodilator use and a FEV1/FVC ratio < 80% are key PFT findings suggestive of asthma.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. Blood investigations reveal total leucocyte count to be >50,000 cells/L. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

 

Neonate with complaints of paroxysm of cough followed by apnea and leucocytosis (>50,000 cells/ L) points to diagnosis of pertussis, for which DOC is Macrolides, i.e., Azithromycin.

 

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

 

A well appearing young child begins to choke, gasp and flail the extremities with face reddened. Apnea and cyanosis may follow the coughing.

 

 

Infants < 3 months do not display the classic stages of whooping cough. Catarrhal phase is usually unnoticed.

 

Treatment – Macrolides

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is not effective against Bordetella pertussis and is not used for the treatment of pertussis.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is an alternative treatment for pertussis in patients who cannot tolerate macrolides but is not the first-line therapy.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: This antibiotic is not typically used for the treatment of pertussis and is not considered the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants presenting with pertussis (whooping cough), characterized by paroxysmal cough and elevated leukocyte count, the drug of choice is azithromycin.

questions.text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autosomal-recessive disorder

 

The pedigree chart shown suggests an autosomal-recessive disorder based on several key observations:

 

  1. Horizontal Pattern: The affected individuals appear in the same generation but are not present in the preceding or subsequent generations. This pattern is characteristic of autosomal-recessive inheritance, where the disorder tends to skip generations unless both parents carry the recessive allele.
  2. Unaffected Parents: Both parents of affected individuals are unaffected, suggesting they are carriers of the recessive allele. In autosomal-recessive inheritance, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to express the disorder.
  3. Carrier Frequency: According to autosomal-recessive inheritance patterns, when both parents are carriers, there is a 25% chance that their offspring will have the disorder (inherit two mutated genes), a 50% chance that the offspring will be carriers (inherit one mutated gene and one normal gene), and a 25% chance that the offspring will have a normal genotype (inherit two normal genes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal-dominant disorder: This pattern typically shows affected individuals in every generation, with both males and females equally likely to inherit the disorder. Affected individuals have a 50% chance of passing the disorder to their offspring, regardless of the other parent's genotype.

 

Option B. X-linked dominant disorder: This pattern would show affected females more frequently if the father is affected and can appear in every generation. However, affected males would pass the condition to all of their daughters and none of their sons.

 

Option D. X-linked recessive disorder: This pattern is more common in males, as they only have one X chromosome. Carrier females would pass the disorder to 50% of their sons, and 50% of their daughters would be carriers. However, in this pedigree, both males and females are affected equally, and the pattern does not suggest an X-linked inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal-recessive disorders are typically characterized by a horizontal pattern of inheritance, where the disorder appears in siblings of the same generation but may skip generations, with unaffected parents often being carriers.

choices.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70 mEg/L

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects multiple systems, primarily the respiratory and digestive systems, due to a defect in the CFTR gene.

 

This is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, CF patients are more likely to experience hypokalemia due to the loss of electrolytes through sweat and the effects of contraction alkalosis.

 

Other Options:

 

The diagnosis and features of cystic fibrosis include:

 

Option A. Sweat chloride test chloride concentration of 70 mEq/L: The sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing CF. A chloride concentration greater than 60 mEq/L is indicative of CF.

 

Option B. Increased immunoreactive trypsinogen level: Newborn screening for CF often includes measuring immunoreactive trypsinogen levels, which are elevated in CF patients.

 

Option D. Contraction alkalosis: CF patients can present with contraction alkalosis due to loss of water and sodium, and renal waste of potassium and hydrogen ions. This is similar to the effects seen in patients taking loop diuretics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, patients with CF may present with hypokalemia and contraction alkalosis due to electrolyte losses.

questions.text: Dried blood spot (DBS) testing is commonly done in infants for: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inborn errors of metabolism.


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is a crucial tool used in neonatal screening for detecting inborn errors of metabolism. This test involves taking a small blood sample from the infant's heel, which is then dried on a filter paper and sent for analysis. Tandem mass spectrometry (TMS) is the primary technique used to analyze the sample for a wide range of metabolic disorders, such as phenylketonuria (PKU), maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), and others. Early detection through DBS testing allows for prompt diagnosis and treatment, significantly improving the prognosis for affected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood grouping: Blood grouping in neonates is typically done in cases of suspected neonatal jaundice to rule out Rh or ABO incompatibility, not using DBS testing.

 

Option C. Bilirubin testing: Bilirubin levels are tested to evaluate jaundice in neonates, particularly in cases of Rh or ABO incompatibility or breastfeeding-related jaundice, but this is not done using DBS.

 

Option D. Coombs Test: The Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that may cause hemolysis in conditions like hemolytic disease of the newborn. It is not performed using dried blood spots.

 

Educational Objective:


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is primarily used for the early detection of inborn errors of metabolism in infants, using tandem mass spectrometry (TMS).

choices.text: It is a mitochondrial storage disorder

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has difficulty walking and getting up from a squatting position. A muscle biopsy was done and is as shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Death occurs in 3rd decade

 

The clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy showing fatty replacement of muscle fibers are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Death in DMD occurs in the late teens and 20s (3rd decade).

 

 

Gower sign:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Previous history of viral prodrome: This option is not correct. DMD is a genetic disorder and does not typically have a history of a viral prodrome.

 

Option C. It is a mitochondrial storage disorder: This option is incorrect. DMD is not a mitochondrial storage disorder; it is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene.

 

Option D. Early treatment has excellent prognosis: While early treatment with corticosteroids can help manage symptoms and slow disease progression, DMD remains a progressive and fatal disease with current treatments. Thus, early treatment does not lead to an "excellent" prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness, and death typically occurs in the late teens to early 20s.

questions.text:
How would you manage a child with status epilepticus? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Airway and breathing
  2. IV Lorazepam
  3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone
  4. IV Fosphenytoin
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 3

 

Status epilepticus is defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness.

 

Status epilepticus is a neurological emergency defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness between episodes. Prompt and systematic management is essential to prevent long-term neurological damage or death.

 

Management Sequence:

 

1. Airway and Breathing: The first priority is to ensure that the airway is open and that the child is breathing adequately. This may involve positioning the child, providing oxygen, and, if necessary, securing the airway with advanced airway management techniques.

 

2. IV Lorazepam: Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the first-line treatment for status epilepticus due to their rapid onset of action and effectiveness in terminating seizures. Lorazepam is typically administered intravenously.

 

4. IV Fosphenytoin: If seizures continue after the administration of a benzodiazepine, IV fosphenytoin (or phenytoin) is used as a second-line agent. It helps to stabilize neuronal membranes and prevent further seizure activity.

 

3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone: These agents are used if seizures persist despite initial treatments. Midazolam can be administered intramuscularly or intravenously, while propofol and thiopentone are typically reserved for refractory status epilepticus and may require the child to be in an intensive care setting due to the need for mechanical ventilation and close monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of status epilepticus in children should follow a systematic approach: securing the airway and ensuring breathing, administering a benzodiazepine, followed by fosphenytoin if seizures persist, and considering more potent agents like midazolam, propofol, or thiopentone if the status epilepticus is refractory to initial treatments.

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from hands precipitated during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy


The clinical presentation described is consistent with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME). JME is characterized by myoclonic jerks, which are sudden, brief, involuntary muscle contractions typically involving both arms. These jerks are most frequent in the morning, often leading to the dropping of objects, as described in this case. The patient maintains consciousness during these episodes, which is typical for JME.

 

Factors supporting the diagnosis:

 

  • Myoclonic jerks: The hallmark seizure type in JME, often occurring shortly after waking up in the morning.
  • Maintained consciousness: The patient remains aware during the myoclonic jerks.
  • Triggers: Seizures can be triggered by stimuli such as sleep deprivation, stress, and photic stimulation (e.g., flashing lights).
  • Genetics: A mutation in the GABRA1 gene is associated with JME.
  • Treatment: Sodium valproate is the drug of choice.
  • Prognosis: Generally good with appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atypical absence: Absence seizures are characterized by brief lapses in consciousness without motor symptoms like dropping objects. Atypical absences last longer than typical ones and have slower onset and resolution.

 

Option C. Choreo-athetoid epilepsy: This condition involves involuntary irregular movements of the face, head, trunk, and extremities, which does not align with the symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Centrotemporal spikes: Benign Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS), also known as Rolandic epilepsy, involves brief stereotypical partial seizures, typically with facial and oropharyngeal involvement, not consistent with the symptomatology in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) is characterized by myoclonic jerks, typically occurring in the morning, with preserved consciousness and a good response to sodium valproate.

questions.text:
What are the components of Nada's Minor Criteria? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Systolic mumur Grade 3
  2. Diastolic murmur
  3. Abnormal second heart sound
  4. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

 

Nada’s criteria is used for detection of CHD on the basis of clinical evaluation.

 

 

Presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria suggest presence of heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Nada’s criteria for detecting congenital heart disease, minor criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure. The presence of one major or two minor criteria suggests the presence of heart disease.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urinalysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, which is a glomerular disease characterized by heavy proteinuria. The diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome is based on the triad of hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), edema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL) in addition to proteinuria >3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio >2.

 

Causes of Nephrotic Syndrome:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Nephritic syndrome: Nephritic syndrome classically presents with tea- or cola-colored urine (hematuria), edema, hypertension, and oliguria.

 

Conditions which present as glomerulonephritis:

 

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy (Option D)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) nephritis

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome also referred to as anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease, is an autoimmune disease that affects both the kidneys and lungs by the formation of autoantibodies that attack their basement membranes. Plasmapheresis is recommended in patients with pauci-immune crescentic GN and Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disorder that occurs when immunoglobulin A (IgA), a protein that helps the body fight infections, settles in the kidneys. This can cause inflammation that, over time, can affect the kidneys' ability to filter waste from the blood. IgA nephropathy is one of the most common glomerulonephritis, a type of kidney disease that affects the glomeruli, the tiny filters within the kidneys that filter waste and excess fluids from the blood.

 

Some common features of IgA nephropathy include:

 

  1. Hematuria: The most common symptom is the presence of blood in the urine (hematuria), which can make the urine appear pink or cola-colored.
  2. Proteinuria: Protein in the urine (proteinuria) may also occur but is typically less significant than in other kidney diseases.
  3. High Blood Pressure: Some individuals may develop high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies in urinalysis

questions.text: A 3-year-old toxic child presents with tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and developed difficulty in swallowing with drooling of saliva within 4-6 hours of fever. Along with airway management. Which of the following needs to be given? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Ceftriaxone

 

The clinical presentation of this 3-year-old child, including tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, dysphagia, and drooling of saliva, suggests acute epiglottitis, a potentially life-threatening condition. Acute epiglottitis is an emergency that can result in airway obstruction due to severe inflammation of the epiglottis and surrounding structures. The management of acute epiglottitis involves the following key steps:

 

  1. Airway Management: Immediate attention to securing the airway is crucial, often requiring endotracheal intubation or, in severe cases, tracheostomy, to prevent airway obstruction.
  2. Empirical Antibiotic Therapy: IV Ceftriaxone is the antibiotic of choice for empirical treatment in acute epiglottitis. Ceftriaxone covers the most common causative organisms, including Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), which is the most frequent pathogen responsible for this condition.
  3. Dexamethasone is often used as adjunctive therapy to reduce airway edema.

 

Once the culture and sensitivity results are available, antibiotic therapy may be adjusted according to the identified pathogen. The immediate empirical use of Ceftriaxone is crucial in managing this condition until further microbiological data is obtained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline: This treatment is typically indicated in cases of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), not in acute epiglottitis. Croup presents with a "barking" cough and usually a more gradual onset compared to epiglottitis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria antitoxin: This is used in the treatment of diphtheria, which presents with a characteristic thick gray pseudomembrane in the throat, and is not related to the clinical features described here. Diphtheria can also cause descending paralysis and other systemic symptoms not seen in this case.

 

Option D. Start steroids: Steroids are indicated in the management of croup to reduce airway inflammation but are not the first-line treatment in epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency requiring immediate airway management and empirical antibiotic therapy, with IV Ceftriaxone being the treatment of choice.

choices.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are  associated with a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is associated with facial angiofibroma 

 

The given image shows discrete nodules over the iris, which are referred to as Lisch nodules, and are commonly seen in patients with neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1). Lisch nodules can present as slightly elevated pigmented areas to distinct ball-like nodules over the iris. Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum) is a feature of tuberous sclerosis and not neurofibromatosis.

 

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

 

 

Note:

 

Lisch nodules are seen in NF-1; however, it can also be seen in NF-2 sometimes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lisch nodules on the iris is associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) and is not associated with facial angiofibroma, which is seen in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, not NF1.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flaccid paralysis

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

 

Cerebral palsy is characterized by abnormalities in muscle tone and movement, including -

 

  • Hypertonia (increased muscle tone),
  • Hypotonia (decreased muscle tone),
  • Ataxia (lack of muscle coordination) is also commonly observed in individuals with cerebral palsy.
  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

 

Seen in conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome, transverse myelitis, poliomyelitis, and traumatic neuritis, but not typically in cerebral palsy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotonia: Can be present in cerebral palsy, characterized by low muscle tone.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: Often associated with cerebral palsy due to brain injury or developmental issues.

 

Option C. Ataxia: Characterized by poor balance and coordination, is a common feature of certain types of cerebral palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy; it is indicative of lower motor neuron disease. Cerebral palsy is characterized by various forms of muscle tone abnormalities and movement disorders.

questions.text: A 15-day-old infant had conjunctivitis, which later developed into respiratory distress and pneumonia. Chest X-ray examination revealed bilateral lung infiltrates. Peripheral smear count showed 14,300/ML (N 43, L 54, and E3). Which of the following is the most likely pathogenic organism? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

The most likely organism causing the infections described in this case is Chlamydia trachomatis. Infants born to women with active, untreated chlamydial infections are at risk of acquiring C. trachomatis, which can lead to neonatal conjunctivitis and pneumonia. The latter is characterized by an insidious onset of symptoms, generally appearing between 1 and 3 months of age.

 

Key clinical features of C. trachomatis pneumonia include a persistent cough, tachypnea (rapid breathing), and the absence of fever, which are typical in affected infants. On auscultation, rales (abnormal breath sounds) are commonly noted, but wheezing is rare, helping to distinguish this type of pneumonia from other respiratory infections such as those caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

 

Laboratory findings often include peripheral eosinophilia (eosinophil count >400 cells/µL), which is a distinctive marker of C. trachomatis pneumonia in infancy. Chest radiographs commonly show hyperinflation of the lungs with minimal interstitial or alveolar infiltrates, which are consistent findings in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: While Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of pneumonia in children, it is less likely in this case because the onset is typically more acute and associated with high fever. Moreover, this bacterium does not usually cause conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Neisseria gonorrhoeae: This pathogen can cause neonatal conjunctivitis, but it is less likely to cause pneumonia. Moreover, Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically causes a more severe conjunctivitis within the first few days of life, not at 15 days of age.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia in older children and young adults, but it is very uncommon in infants. It also does not typically present with the characteristic features described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chlamydia trachomatis can cause neonatal conjunctivitis and pneumonia, typically presenting with an insidious onset of cough, tachypnea, absence of fever, and peripheral eosinophilia in infants aged 1 to 3 months.

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Any of the above

 

Occult spinal dysraphism is a condition where there is a defect in the fusion of midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures, and it can be presented in newborns with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. Typically, patients with occult spinal dysraphism have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, such as a small dimple, a tuft of hair, or a subcutaneous lipoma. These abnormalities can be a sign of underlying spinal cord abnormalities, and it's important to evaluate them thoroughly to rule out any serious underlying conditions.

 

Spinal dysraphism includes-

 

Open spinal dysraphism: Myelomeningocele, meningocele

Occult spinal dysraphism:

  • Spina bifida occulta
  • Spinal lipoma
  • Dermal sinus
  • Tethered cord
  • Split cord malformation (diastematomyelia)
  • And others
     

 

 

 

The initial investigation is usually ultrasound in the neonate and the best investigation is MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn may indicate occult spinal dysraphism, which includes conditions such as spina bifida occulta, spinal lipoma, and dermal sinus, all of which can be signs of underlying spinal abnormalities requiring thorough evaluation, typically starting with ultrasound and definitive imaging with MRI.

choices.text: D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with seizures. His past history is significant for an episode of fever with rash at 1 year of age which resolved spontaneously. What is the most helpful investigation to diagnose his condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgG measles in CSF

 

This patient is most likely suffering from subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), also known as Dawson disease, which is caused by infection with the measles virus. The CSF anti-measles antibodies - IgG antibodies will be elevated and hence, it is the most helpful investigation to diagnose this condition.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis: Mesial temporal lobe sclerosis is associated with temporal lobe epilepsy, not SSPE. It involves scarring in the temporal lobe but is not typically seen in SSPE.

 

Option C. IgM measles in CSF: IgM antibodies indicate a recent infection. In SSPE, the infection occurred years earlier, so IgG antibodies, not IgM, would be elevated in the CSF.

 

Option D. D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF: D C1Q4 antibodies are not relevant to the diagnosis of SSPE. These antibodies are associated with complement component 1q deficiency, which is linked to autoimmune conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), elevated CSF anti-measles IgG antibodies are key for diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the rate of increment of head circumference in the first three months of life?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 cm per month

 

During the first three months of life, the head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month. This rapid growth is due to the significant brain development occurring during this period. After the first three months, the growth rate slows down. From three to six months of age, the head circumference increases by about 1 cm per month, and from six months to one year, it increases by about 0.5 cm per month.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first three months of life.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with features of respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. There is a history of upper respiratory infection. The radiograph is shown below. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

 

A child with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor and given radiograph points to a diagnosis of acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

 

LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS (CROUP)

 

  • Viral infection of glottis & subglottic region
  • Caused by Parainfluenza virus
  • Symptoms: hoarse voice, coryza, mild Tachypnea

 

Treatment –

 

  • Nebulized racemic adrenaline (1:1 mixture of d & I isomers)
  • A single dose of dexamethasone (0.3--0.6 mg/kg, intramuscular) reduces seventy, if given within the first 24 hours.
  • Antibiotics not indicated

 

NOTE -

 

Croup decreases in lying down position and Laryngomalacia increases on lying down

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis patients, usually 3-6 years of age, present with acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia and drooling. The patient looks toxic and sits in tripod position, sitting upright, leaning forward with chin up. Treatment is IV Ceftriaxone. Lateral neck X-ray reveals thickening of the epiglottis (thumb print sign).

 

 

Option C. Foreign body in glottis: Aspiration of foreign body may result in localized area of wheeze, hyperresonance and reduced air entry. Foreign bodies are removed through a rigid bronchoscope.

 

Option D. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is M/C cause of congenital laryngeal anomaly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral infection of the glottis and subglottic region, often caused by the Parainfluenza virus, and presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital with high-grade fever and altered consciousness. On examination, the patient had neck rigidity and pain when bending the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed and it showed a WBC count of 1500 cells/ L, majority being neutrophils, elevated pressure with protein of 120 mg/dL, and a CSF glucose level of 70 mg dL & blood glucose level - 300 mg dL). How will you manage the index case? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vancomycin + ceftriaxone

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory results provided strongly suggest a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. The CSF analysis shows significant findings including a high WBC count predominantly composed of neutrophils, elevated protein, and a relatively low CSF glucose level considering the elevated blood glucose. The CSF glucose level, when compared to the blood glucose, gives a ratio that is suggestive of bacterial meningitis (a ratio of 0.4 or less is highly indicative).

 

Meningitis can present with symptoms such as high-grade fever, altered consciousness, neck rigidity, and positive meningeal signs like Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs. The diagnosis is confirmed by CSF analysis, which typically shows:

 

  • Neutrophilic pleocytosis
  • Increased protein levels
  • Decreased glucose concentrations
  • Presence of microorganisms on Gram stain and culture

 

The initial treatment of bacterial meningitis should include broad-spectrum antibiotics that cover the most common pathogens. A combination of a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone and vancomycin is recommended to cover for Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Piperacillin + tazobactam: Piperacillin + tazobactam is used in certain situations such as hospital-acquired infections or when there is no response to ceftriaxone. However, it is not the first-line treatment for community-acquired bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Amphotericin + flucytosine: Amphotericin + flucytosine are antifungal agents used to treat fungal meningitis, not bacterial meningitis. Fungal meningitis presents differently and typically in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Antitubercular therapy: Antitubercular therapy is considered when the CSF profile shows low glucose, high protein, and lymphocytic predominance, which is typical for tuberculous meningitis. The provided CSF findings do not match those of tuberculous meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin combined with a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone is the recommended initial treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis.

choices.text: Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes
No need for long term antiepileptics

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about febrile seizure?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 54% recurrence

 

Febrile seizures are convulsions brought on by a fever in infants or small children. They are relatively common and typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years. The main features of febrile seizures include:

 

  • Age 6 months – 5 years: This is the typical age range for febrile seizures, making this statement true.
  • Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes: Simple febrile seizures are brief, usually lasting less than 15 minutes. This statement is also true.
  • No need for long term antiepileptic: In the case of simple febrile seizures, long-term antiepileptic treatment is generally not necessary. This statement is true as well.

 

The statement "54% recurrence" is not true. The recurrence rate for febrile seizures is significantly lower. While there is a risk of recurrence, it is not as high as 54%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febrile seizures typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years, last less than 15 minutes, and do not require long-term antiepileptic treatment. The recurrence rate is much lower than 54%.

choices.text: Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body
In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation
The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis

questions.text: A previously healthy child presented with acute-onset dyspnea. A chest X-ray shows unilateral hyperinflation of the lungs. What is true for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body

 

The clinical presentation suggests the presence of a foreign body in the airway, most likely in the bronchi, causing incomplete airway obstruction. This would be evident on auscultation as a focal area of decreased air entry. This condition is more common in children under 4 years old, and food items are the most common foreign bodies. Non-irritating types, such as plastic, glass, or metallic foreign bodies, and irritating types, such as vegetables, peanuts, beans, and seeds, are frequently encountered. The right bronchus is more susceptible to foreign body impaction because it is wider and more in line with the tracheal lumen.

 

Evaluation:

 

  • A plain X-ray chest in posteroanterior and lateral views (expiratory films are useful) is performed to evaluate a foreign body in the airway.
  • The X-ray may show the radio-opaque foreign body's size, shape, and location, lobar or segmental atelectasis in complete airway obstruction, or hyperinflation or obstructive emphysema of the affected area due to the ball valve mechanism.

 

Management:

 

  • The management of foreign body airway depends on the location of the foreign body.
  • A laryngeal foreign body can be treated with the Heimlich maneuver, and if it fails, cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be performed.
  • Foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi can be removed using a rigid bronchoscope after adequate hydration and emptying of the stomach.
  • Appropriate antibiotics are given to prevent secondary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexible bronchoscopy used for removal: Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred over flexible bronchoscopy for the removal of foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi because it allows better visualization and manipulation.

 

Option C. In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation: Incomplete obstruction, not complete obstruction, is associated with the ball valve mechanism, which causes hyperinflation by allowing air to enter but not leave the affected area.

 

Option D. The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, is caused by the parainfluenza virus. It commonly affects children aged 6 months to 3 years and presents with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever. The chest X-ray shows a narrowing of the subglottic region known as the steeple sign, which is not consistent with the presented case of foreign body aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute-onset dyspnea with unilateral hyperinflation on chest X-ray, a focal area of decreased air entry is suggestive of foreign body aspiration, which is more common in children under 4 years old.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aqueductal stenosis

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly (enlargement of ventricles of the brain) in newborns. It is a congenital condition where there is narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a small channel that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. This obstruction can result in an enlargement of the ventricles, which can lead to hydrocephalus (accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain). Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker syndrome, and arachnoid villi malformation are other conditions that can cause ventriculomegaly, but they are less common causes than aqueductal stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arnold chiari malformation: Arnold chiari malformation will have downward displacement of cerebellum and brainstem. This is not the most commonest cause of ventriculomegaly

 

Option B. Dandy walker malformation: Dandy walker malformation will have cerebellar hypoplasia with hydrocephalus.

 

Option C. Arachnoid villi malformation: Arachnoid villi malformation is not the most commonest cause

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the leading cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns due to the narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, leading to hydrocephalus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Downs syndrome?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudal regression syndrome

 

  • Caudal regression syndrome is not typically associated with Down syndrome. Caudal regression syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by abnormal development of the lower spine (caudal region). It is a separate condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a known association with Down syndrome. 

 

Option B. Hearing loss: Hearing loss is commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Ear infections and structural abnormalities may contribute to this condition.

 

Option C. Short stature: Short stature is a characteristic feature of Down syndrome. Individuals with Down syndrome often have a shorter stature compared to the general population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the common clinical features and associated conditions of Down syndrome. Understand that hypothyroidism, hearing loss, and short stature are commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Be aware of the distinct features of other congenital conditions, such as caudal regression syndrome, that are not typically associated with Down syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is an X-linked disorder? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Color blindness

 

Among the options given, color blindness is an X-linked disorder.

 

Color blindness is a condition in which an individual has difficulty distinguishing between different colors. It is caused by a genetic mutation that affects the development or function of the photopigments in the retina of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thalassemia: Thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, and cystic fibrosis are not X-linked disorders. They are all Autosomal recessive inheritance. Thalassemia is an inherited blood disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: Sickle cell anemia is also an inherited blood disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, leading to the formation of abnormal, sickle-shaped red blood cells.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disorder that affects the production and function of mucus, leading to the buildup of thick, sticky mucus in the lungs and other organs.

 

These conditions are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, meaning that both parents must carry a mutated gene to pass the condition on to their children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Color blindness is an X-linked disorder, meaning that the gene causing the condition is located on the X chromosome, which primarily affects males and is passed down from carrier mothers.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with altered sensorium, persistent headache, and photophobia for the past 5 days. On examination, he has signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals:what is your diagnosis?
Protein: 93 mg/dL


Glucose: 20 mg/dL (serum glucose = 90 mg/dL)


Cell count: Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is often associated with CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. These findings are consistent with the given CSF results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: The CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and an increased number of neutrophil predominance (not lymphocytes) are suggestive of meningitis. However, bacterial meningitis is more commonly associated with a significantly higher white blood cell count (pleocytosis) in the CSF. The given CSF results are not typical for bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Viral meningitis: This is a potential consideration. Viral meningitis can present with elevated protein, normal or mildly reduced glucose, and an increased number of lymphocytes in the CSF. It is a common cause of aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which vaccine is typically stored in the lowest compartment of the ILR? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) OPV

 

In an Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR), vaccines are stored at specific temperatures to maintain their potency. The lowest compartment of the ILR is the coldest part, which is optimal for storing vaccines that require the coldest temperatures. Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is stored in the lowest compartment because it requires the coldest storage conditions to remain effective.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penta: Pentavalent vaccine (which protects against five diseases: diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenzae type b) does not require the lowest temperature and is generally stored in the middle compartments.

 

Option B. DPT: The DPT vaccine (Diphtheria, Pertussis, and Tetanus) does not need to be stored in the coldest compartment and is kept in the upper or middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Option C. Hep B: The Hepatitis B vaccine also does not require the lowest storage temperature and is kept in the middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) should be stored in the lowest compartment of the Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR) due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions.

questions.text: You have been called to declare the brain death of a 12-year-old child in the ICU. Which of the following is not seen in brain death? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decorticate and decerebrate posturing

 

Brain death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all brain activity, including the brainstem. It is a clinical diagnosis based on the absence of neurological function and the irreversible loss of the capacity for consciousness and spontaneous respiration.

 

In brain death, the following clinical observations can be present and may be mistakenly interpreted as signs of brainstem function, but they do not indicate any meaningful brain activity:

 

Things That Can Be Present in Brain Death- 

  1. Normal blood pressure without drugs
  2. Spinal reflexes
    1. Movements like Babinski, deep tendon reflexes may be seen.
    2. These come from the spinal cord, not the brain
  3. Sweating or tachycardia
    1. Autonomic responses — do not indicate brain activity.
  4. What is Not Seen in Brain Death:
    1. Decorticate or decerebrate posturing
      1. These need some brain activity
      2. In brain death: no such posturing happens — total motor silence.


         

 

However, decorticate and decerebrate posturing are not seen in brain death. These postures are indicative of severe brain injury but require some level of brain activity to generate the motor response. In brain death, all brain-originating motor responses, including these postures, are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal BP without pharmacological support: Autonomic responses may still maintain blood pressure without brain function, making this observation consistent with brain death.

 

Option B. Positive spinal reflexes on stimulation: These reflexes are mediated by the spinal cord, not the brain, and thus can still occur in brain death.

 

Option C. Sweating and tachycardia: These autonomic functions can persist despite brain death due to residual autonomic nervous system activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain death is characterized by the complete absence of brain-originating motor responses, including decorticate and decerebrate posturing, despite possible preservation of autonomic functions like normal BP and spinal reflexes.

questions.text:
Which of the following increase the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Age < 1 year
  2. Temperature of 38-39°C
  3. Duration of fever < 24 h
  4. Duration of fever > 48 h
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children who are less than 1 year old, have a fever with a temperature between 38-39°C, and have a fever duration of less than 24 hours. Febrile seizures typically occur in children between the ages of 6 and 60 months and are generalized tonic-clonic seizures that occur in the setting of fever without any underlying intracranial infection or a previous history of unprovoked seizures.

 

Risk Factors:

 

1. Age < 1 year: Younger age increases the likelihood of recurrent febrile seizures.

 

2. Temperature of 38-39°C: Lower fever temperatures (38-39°C) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

3. Duration of fever < 24 h: A shorter duration of fever before the onset of seizures is associated with an increased risk of recurrence.

 

Other Information:

 

  • Minor risk factors for recurrence include male gender, attending daycare, having complex febrile seizures, a family history of febrile seizures, and lower serum sodium levels at presentation.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Duration of fever > 48 hours: A duration of fever greater than 48 hours is not considered a risk factor for febrile seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children under 1 year of age, with fever temperatures between 38-39°C, and fever lasting less than 24 hours.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the left lung. What would be the correct management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Bronchoscopy
  2. Computed tomography scan
  3. ICD insertion
  4. Chest x-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 4

 

A child presenting with a history of choking and decreased air entry in the left lung is highly suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the left bronchus. The correct management steps include:

 

1. Bronchoscopy: This is the gold standard for both the diagnosis and removal of the foreign body. Rigid bronchoscopy is typically performed by a specialist, such as an otolaryngologist or pulmonologist, to visualize and extract the foreign body.

 

4. Chest X-ray: This is an essential initial investigation to assess for the presence of a foreign body. Although many foreign bodies are radiolucent, secondary findings such as air trapping, obstructive emphysema, atelectasis, asymmetric hyperinflation, mediastinal shift, and consolidation can be indicative of foreign body aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

2. CT scan: While a CT scan has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting radiolucent foreign bodies, it is not routinely performed in this situation due to the high radiation exposure, especially in children.

 

3. ICD insertion: Insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD) is not indicated unless there is clinical evidence of pneumothorax or other complications that require it. A chest X-ray is essential before deciding on this intervention.

 

Clinical Approach:

 

  • A detailed history and physical examination are critical when a child presents with choking.
  • A chest X-ray should be performed to assess for secondary signs of foreign body aspiration.
  • Bronchoscopy should be conducted even if imaging is negative but clinical suspicion remains high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, a chest X-ray and bronchoscopy are the key steps for diagnosis and management. Bronchoscopy allows for both visualization and removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

 

The best advice for the exposed students is to receive antibiotic prophylaxis. This is recommended for close contacts of a person with meningococcal meningitis, such as household members, intimate contacts, and anyone who has had direct contact with the patient's oral secretions. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated as soon as possible after exposure and can be effective in preventing secondary cases of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Two doses of polysaccharide vaccine: While vaccination is important, it takes time to provide protection. Therefore, it is not the best option for immediate protection in this situation.

 

Option C. Two doses of conjugate vaccine: The conjugate vaccine is recommended for adolescents and children, but similar to the polysaccharide vaccine, it does not provide immediate protection. Antibiotic prophylaxis is still necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Option D. Single dose of meningococcal vaccine: Again, vaccination alone is not sufficient for immediate protection, and antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

questions.text: A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which revealed periventricular calcifications. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine examination

 

Based on the clinical presentation, it appears that congenital cytomegalovirus infection is a likely diagnosis. The most effective method for diagnosing the specific cause of the infection is by examining urine samples. In order to diagnose congenital CMV infection, the best specimens to use for culture are urine and saliva, while the best specimens for PCR testing are saliva and cord blood.

 

Clinical features:

 

  1. Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
  2. Prematurity
  3. Hepatosplenomegaly
  4. Jaundice
  5. Blueberry-muffin-like rash
  6. Thrombocytopenia, purpura
  7. Microcephaly,
  8. Intracranial calcifications
  9. Chorioretinitis
  10. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
  11. Mild increases in CSF protein.

 

Rx: Ganciclovir can limit hearing loss and improve the developmental outcome in symptomatically infected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver biopsy: liver biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice in Wilson disease.

 

Option C. Blood examination: Blood examination will not give us the diagnostic results.

 

Option D. CSF examination: CSF examination is useful in cases of meningitis or neonatal sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urine examination is the preferred diagnostic method for identifying congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which typically presents with symptoms such as intrauterine growth restriction, prematurity, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and periventricular calcifications.

questions.text: Craniopagus is defined as the fusion of? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head only

 

Craniopagus refers to a type of conjoined twins where the twins are fused at the cranium (head). This type of conjoined twin fusion involves the skulls but does not typically involve the face or the foramen magnum. Although the brains of craniopagus twins are usually separate, there may be some shared brain tissue, which can sometimes be discovered.

 

Craniopagus twins generally have fused skulls and meninges (the membranes covering the brain), making separation surgeries particularly complex and risky. These twins are genetically identical and are always of the same sex.

 

Craniopagus occurs in approximately 5% of conjoined twin cases, and the prognosis after separation surgery is often poor due to the complexity of the shared structures.

 

Types of Conjoined Twins:

 

  • Abdomen (omphalopagus): Fusion occurs at the abdomen.
  • Chest (thoracopagus): Fusion occurs at the thorax.
  • Top of head down to the belly button, facing each other (cephalopagus): Fusion occurs from the top of the head down to the belly button.
  • Head only (craniopagus): Fusion occurs at the cranium.
  • Pelvis, facing each other (ischiopagus): Fusion occurs at the pelvis with the twins facing each other.
  • Pelvis, side-to-side (parapagus): Fusion occurs at the pelvis with the twins side-by-side.
  • Vertebral column (rachipagus): Fusion occurs at the vertebral column.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head and spine: This type of fusion is not characteristic of craniopagus, which involves only the head.

 

Option C. Thorax and spine: This type of fusion does not apply to craniopagus twins but could describe other forms like thoracopagus or rachipagus.

 

Option D. Thorax only: This describes thoracopagus twins, where the fusion occurs at the thorax, not the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopagus is a specific type of conjoined twins where the fusion occurs only at the cranium (head), and these twins are genetically identical and of the same sex.

questions.text: A woman came to OPD with a newborn who has complaints of chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The paediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lecithin

 

Newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome which is due to surfactant deficiency, i.e., lecithin.

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Hyaline Membrane Disease)

 

 

The newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, which is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and maintaining proper lung function. Lecithin, also known as dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC), is the most important component of surfactant. A deficiency in lecithin leads to insufficient surfactant production, resulting in alveolar collapse, reduced functional residual capacity (FRC), and the clinical features observed in RDS.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Dipalmitoyl inositol: This is not a component of surfactant. The main components of surfactant are phospholipids like lecithin and other proteins.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While present in amniotic fluid and used in the lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio to assess fetal lung maturity, it is not the primary component of surfactant.

 

Option D. Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylethanolamine: This is a phospholipid but not a primary component of surfactant involved in preventing alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant, particularly lecithin (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).

questions.text: One mother had brought her child for evaluation of diphtheria in which the child had low-grade fever, pseudomembranes over the tonsils, and one sibling is fully immunized. What will be the prophylaxis given to her sibling? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythromycin

 

The Ans. is Erythromycin. In cases where a household member is diagnosed with diphtheria, all close contacts, including fully immunized siblings, should be given prophylactic treatment regardless of their immunization status.

 

The recommended prophylaxis for contacts is oral Erythromycin for seven days or a single dose of benzathine penicillin. This approach aims to prevent the spread of Corynebacterium diphtheriae and the development of active diphtheria lesions in contacts, even if they are asymptomatic and immunized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria booster single dose: A booster dose of the diphtheria toxoid is recommended for previously immunized individuals who are diagnosed with diphtheria but are asymptomatic. This does not apply to the contact sibling who is already fully immunized and not infected.

 

Option C. Diphtheria toxoid full course: A full course of the diphtheria toxoid is not necessary for a fully immunized sibling who is a contact. This option would be considered for individuals who are not up-to-date with their diphtheria vaccinations.

 

Option D. Nothing is required: This option is incorrect because all household contacts of a diphtheria case should receive prophylactic treatment to prevent possible infection and transmission, even if they are asymptomatic and fully immunized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fully immunized close contacts of a diphtheria case, the recommended prophylaxis is a seven-day course of oral Erythromycin or a single dose of benzathine penicillin.
