questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding ataxia-telangiectasia? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follows autosomal dominant mode inheritance

 

The mode of inheritance in ataxia-telangiectasia is autosomal recessive.

 

Ataxia telangiectasia:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene on chromosome 11, characterized by defective DNA repair, immunodeficiency, progressive neurological degeneration, and increased risk of malignancies.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydration

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. Aggressive hydration is the next best step in the management of this condition.

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) can occur after chemotherapy due to release of intracellular components.
  • Increased uric acid levels cause hyperuricemia, while release of potassium and phosphate leads to hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Hyperphosphatemia leads to reciprocal depression of serum calcium causing hypocalcemia.
  • TLS can result in renal failure due to deposition of uric acid crystals, calcium phosphate, and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Signs and symptoms of TLS include abdominal pain, dysuria, oliguria, flank pain, anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, altered mental status, tetany, weakness, and paralysis.
  • The Cairo-Bishop criteria are used to assess the severity of TLS.
  • Management of TLS includes measuring electrolytes and aggressive hydration before starting therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Probenecid: Probenecid inhibits the organic anion transporter in the nephron, thereby inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid. However, it is contraindicated in TLS as it increases the risk of uric acid stones due to increased uric acid levels.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors that decrease uric acid synthesis and treat hyperuricemia. While they are useful in managing hyperuricemia, aggressive hydration is the first-line treatment in TLS to prevent renal failure.

 

Option D. Rasburicase: Rasburicase is an enzyme that degrades uric acid and is preferred in TLS over allopurinol for rapidly reducing uric acid levels. However, initial aggressive hydration is crucial before administering rasburicase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aggressive hydration is the first-line management for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) to prevent renal failure and facilitate the excretion of released intracellular components.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination, he has fever with fontanelle bulging and the child was lethargic. The most probable cause is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meningitis

 

Poor eating, fever, convulsions, a bulging fontanelle, and lethargy are all symptoms of meningitis.

 

Meningococcus, Streptococcus pneumonia, or Haemophilus influenza type b can all cause bacterial meningitis. General symptoms include fever, lethargy, unwillingness to feed, vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Febrile seizure: Patient should have a history of high grade fever associated with seizures.

 

Option C. Pseudotumor cerebri: This is the most common type of focal seizure present in sleep. Age group 3-10 yr, resolve by adolescence. Start at night in the form of buccal throat tingling, tonic clonic contraction of one side with preserved consciousness.

 

Option D. Intracranial hemorrhage: Patient should have history of any trauma

 

Seizures and localised neurological symptoms are possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Poor eating, fever, convulsions, a bulging fontanelle, and lethargy are all symptoms of meningitis.

questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acoustic neuromas 

 

In neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), two or more of the following clinical manifestations are present:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic neuromas are not a diagnostic criterion for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1); they are typically associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2). The diagnostic criteria for NF1 include the presence of café-au-lait macules, axillary or inguinal freckling, Lisch nodules, neurofibromas, sphenoid dysplasia, optic gliomas, and a first-degree relative with NF1.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine

 

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency is a well-known cause of refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is crucial for the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), which plays a key role in inhibiting neural activity. A deficiency in pyridoxine can disrupt neurotransmitter balance, leading to seizures that are often difficult to control with standard anticonvulsant therapy.

 

Neonatal seizures caused by pyridoxine deficiency typically present within the first few hours to days of life. These seizures are often clonic in nature and may involve multiple foci. The underlying cause of pyridoxine-dependent seizures is typically a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene, which impairs the ability of an enzyme to break down I-alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde, leading to a buildup of toxic substances that affect brain function.

 

Prompt administration of pyridoxine can rapidly resolve the seizures, making it an essential diagnostic and therapeutic consideration in neonates presenting with unexplained seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with neurological disorders like Wernicke's encephalopathy and beriberi, but it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Option C. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, but it is not commonly linked to neonatal seizures.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) deficiency is extremely rare and is associated with symptoms like fatigue, depression, and irritability, but it does not typically cause neonatal seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in neonates, and recognizing this condition is crucial because these seizures can be rapidly treated with pyridoxine supplementation.
